Data.String: The conceptual content of an :sp:element:`~Core.EngineeringModel`, i.e., engineering information independent from its graphical representation.
The abstract base class of all classes used in a :sp:element:`~Core.ConceptualModel`.

A container for one or more :sp:element:`~Core.DataTypes.SingleLanguageString`'s. :sp:element:`!~Core.DataTypes.MultiLanguageString` is used as the type of data attributes which have language-dependent string values.
The value that can be tolerated for an extended period. It has a specific meaning in safety specifications.
The value is that used for design. It has a specific meaning in safety specifications.
A value that is estimated and subject to uncertainty.
The value that can be tolerated for a short period. It has a specific meaning in safety specifications.
The value initiates a protective action.
A value assigned by the manufacturer representing a specified operating condition.
The value that will be set to test a system or piece of equipment.

The language of the :sp:element:`~Core.DataTypes.SingleLanguageString.Value` of the :sp:element:`~Core.DataTypes.SingleLanguageString`. If not :sp:element:`~Builtin.Undefined`, the language must be given as a language tag standardized by IETF BCP 47 (Best Current Practice 47 by the Internet Engineering Task Force). IETF BCP 47 is based on ISO 639.

A :sp:element:`!~Core.DataTypes.SingleLanguageString` contains a :sp:element:`~Core.DataTypes.SingleLanguageString.Value` and a :sp:element:`~Core.DataTypes.SingleLanguageString.Language` tag. :sp:element:`!~Core.DataTypes.SingleLanguageString` is only used within :sp:element:`~Core.DataTypes.MultiLanguageString`.
Basic data types such as strings, numbers, and enumerations.
The intensity of the blue channel of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Color`.
The intensity of the green channel of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Color`.
The intensity of the red channel of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Color`.

A color.
:sp:element:`!~Core.Diagram.Color` is based on the RGB color model (e.g., see `Wikipedia <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RGB_color_spaces>`__ for an overview). For each channel *red*, *green*, and *blue*, :sp:element:`!~Core.Diagram.Color` has an attribute :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Color.R`, :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Color.G`, and :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Color.B` that gives the intensity of the channel. Intensities are given as values of :sp:element:`~Core.DataTypes.UnsignedByte`, i.e., integers in the range [0, 255].

Simplified Literals -------------------
Within this specification, we use the hexadecimal SVG representation of a :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Color` (without the string delimiters) as a convenient literal to refer to that :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Color`.
For example, :code:`#0000ff` refers to the :sp:element:`<Core.Diagram.Color>` *blue* with :code:`R=0`, :code:`G=0`, and :code:`B=255`.
Mapping to SVG --------------
There are several syntactical variants to map a :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Color` to SVG. Here, we use the `RGB Hexadecimal Notation <https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-4/#hex-notation>`__ with 6 digits as defined by :ref:`standard-css-color-4`. It has the form :code:`'#RRGGBB'`, where :code:`RR`, :code:`GG`, and :code:`BB` are 2-digit hexadecimal representations of the integer values of the attributes :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Color.R`, :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Color.G`, and :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Color.B`. Conventional hexadecimal digits are used: :code:`0`, ..., :code:`9`, :code:`a`, ..., :code:`f`. Capitalized versions of the latter are also allowed: :code:`A`, ..., :code:`F`. To ensure 2 digits for each integer, a leading zero is added if required.
.. admonition:: example
Consider the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Color` with :code:`R=0`, :code:`G=10`, and :code:`B=255`.
The hexadecimal representations of the attributes are :code:`00`, :code:`0a`, and :code:`ff`.
Hence, the SVG representation of the color is :code:`'#000aff'`.

A :sp:element:`!~Core.Diagram.DashStyle` describes a pattern for drawing a stroke. The pattern gives the lengths of those parts of a stroke that are actually drawn and of those parts that are not drawn.

Appearance ==========
Each :sp:element:`!~Core.Diagram.DashStyle` is characterized by a sequence of an even number of double values. The first of these values gives the length of a visible part of a stroke, the second one the length of an invisible part. Optional further pairs of double values in the pattern are applied in the same way. The entire pattern is applied repeatedly until the end of a stroke.
The lengths in a :sp:element:`!~Core.Diagram.DashStyle`'s pattern are given in terms of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke`'s :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke.Width` in mm, i.e., the dimensionless double values must be multiplied with the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke.Width` in order to get the actual lengths.
The following table gives heuristically proven patterns for the different :sp:element:`DashStyles <Core.Diagram.DashStyle>`.
.. image:: /images/img5.*
The length of the horizontal semi-axis of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Ellipse` in mm.
The rotation of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Ellipse` around its center, measured clockwise and in degrees. The value must be in the inverval [0; 360).
The length of the vertical semi-axis of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Ellipse` in mm.

Geometry ========
The geometry of an :sp:element:`!~Core.Diagram.Ellipse` is characterized by its :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Ellipse.Center`, its two axes (:sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Ellipse.HorizontalSemiAxis` and :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Ellipse.VerticalSemiAxis`), and the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Ellipse.Rotation` of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Ellipse.HorizontalSemiAxis` w.r.t. the x axis of the :ref:`owner <owner-of-graphical-primitive>`. The :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Ellipse.Rotation` is measured clockwise and in degrees.
.. admonition:: example
We consider an :sp:element:`!~Core.Diagram.Ellipse` with
- :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Ellipse.Center` :code:`(10, 20)`,
- :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Ellipse.HorizontalSemiAxis` :code:`110`,
- :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Ellipse.VerticalSemiAxis` :code:`50`, and
- :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Ellipse.Rotation` :code:`35`.
The :sp:element:`!~Core.Diagram.Ellipse` will look like this:
.. image:: /images/img15.*
.. rubric:: Visual Center
The :ref:`visual center <visual-center>` of an :sp:element:`!~Core.Diagram.Ellipse` is its actual :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Ellipse.Center`.
Mapping to SVG ==============
An :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Ellipse` corresponds to an `svg:ellipse <https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG2/shapes.html#EllipseElement>`__ with these attributes:
- :code:`transform` describes both the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Ellipse.Center` :math:`(c_x, c_y)` and the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Ellipse.Rotation` :math:`r` of the Ellipse.
:code:`transform = "translate(` + str(:math:`c_x`) + :code:`,` + str(:math:`c_y`) + :code:`) rotate(` + str(:math:`r`) + :code:`)"`
- :code:`rx` and :code:`ry` are string representations of :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Ellipse.HorizontalSemiAxis` and :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Ellipse.VerticalSemiAxis`.
- :code:`stroke`, :code:`stroke-dasharray`, :code:`stroke-dashoffset` and :code:`stroke-width` are set according to the SVG mapping rules for the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Ellipse.Stroke` of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Ellipse` (see :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke`).
- :code:`stroke-linecap = "round"` and :code:`stroke-linejoin = "round"` reflect the :ref:`heuristic for line caps and line joins <line-caps-and-line-joins>`.
- :code:`vector-effect = "non-scaling-stroke"` reflects the :ref:`heuristic for scaled symbols <scaled-symbols>`.
- :code:`fill` is set according to the SVG mapping rules for the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Ellipse.FillStyle` of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Ellipse` (see :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.FillStyle`).
.. admonition:: example
We assume that the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke` of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Ellipse` above is :code:`2mm #ff0000 Solid` and that its :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Ellipse.FillStyle` is :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.FillStyle.Transparent`.
.. code-block:: xml
{EllipseTransparentSvgCode}
.. image:: /images/img16.*
.. admonition:: example
We consider the same :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Ellipse` as in the previous example, except that the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke` is :code:`2mm #ff0000 LongDashShortDash`.
.. code-block:: xml
{EllipseLongDashShortDashSvgCode}
.. image:: /images/img17.*
.. admonition:: example
Finally, a variant with :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke` :code:`2mm #ff0000 Solid` and :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Ellipse.FillStyle` :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.FillStyle.Hatch`.
.. code-block:: xml
{EllipseHatchSvgCode}
.. image:: /images/img18.*
The end angle of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc`, measured clockwise and in degrees. The value must be in the inverval [0; 360).
The length of the horizontal semi-axis of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc` in mm.
The rotation of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc` around its center, measured clockwise and in degrees. The value must be in the inverval [0; 360).
The start angle of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc`, measured clockwise and in degrees. The value must be in the inverval [0; 360).
The length of the vertical semi-axis of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc` in mm.

Geometry ========
An :sp:element:`!~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc` is a segment of an ellipse. The geometry of the underlying ellipse is described in the same way as the geometry of the actual :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Ellipse` class (:sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc.Center`, :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc.HorizontalSemiAxis`, :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc.VerticalSemiAxis`, :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc.Rotation`). In addition, an :sp:element:`!~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc` has two attributes :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc.StartAngle` and :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc.EndAngle` that determine the start and end position of the arc.
.. admonition:: example
We consider an :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc` with
- :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc.Center` :code:`(10, 20)`,
- :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc.HorizontalSemiAxis` :code:`110`,
- :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc.VerticalSemiAxis` :code:`50`, and
- :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc.Rotation` :code:`35`.
These attributes describe the blue dashed ellipse in this figure (cf. the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Ellipse` example which has the same attribute values).
.. image:: /images/img19.*
The :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc` has two further geometric attributes
- :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc.StartAngle` :code:`288` and
- :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc.EndAngle` :code:`20`.
These two angles do not have a simple geometric interpretation in the figure; we will get back to them in the following sections. However, these angles determine the start position and the end position of the black :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc` in the figure. The actual :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc` goes from the start position *in positive direction* (i.e., clockwise) to the end position.
.. rubric:: Calculation of start and end position
We use the following notation:
- :math:`c_x` and :math:`c_y`: components of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc.Center`,
- :math:`r_x`: :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc.HorizontalSemiAxis`,
- :math:`r_y`: :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc.VerticalSemiAxis`,
- :math:`\varphi`: :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc.Rotation`,
- :math:`\theta_1`: :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc.StartAngle`,
- :math:`\theta_2`: :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc.EndAngle`,
- :math:`x_1` and :math:`y_1`: start position,
- :math:`x_2` and :math:`y_2`: end position.
.. admonition:: technical
The notation is based on that used by the `SVG Arc Implementation Notes <https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG2/implnote.html#ArcImplementationNotes>`__ which may be useful for implementors.
The start position is
.. math::
\left(\begin{array}{c} x_1 \\ y_1 \end{array}\right) = \left(\begin{array}{cc} \cos \varphi & -\sin \varphi \\ \sin \varphi & \cos \varphi \end{array}\right) \cdotp \left(\begin{array}{c} r_x \cos \theta_1 \\ r_y \sin \theta_1 \end{array}\right) + \left(\begin{array}{c} c_x \\ c_y \end{array}\right)
and the end position is
.. math::
\left(\begin{array}{c} x_2 \\ y_2 \end{array}\right) = \left(\begin{array}{cc} \cos \varphi & -\sin \varphi \\ \sin \varphi & \cos \varphi \end{array}\right) \cdotp \left(\begin{array}{c} r_x \cos \theta_2 \\ r_y \sin \theta_2 \end{array}\right) + \left(\begin{array}{c} c_x \\ c_y \end{array}\right) \quad .
.. admonition:: example
In the example, we have
.. math::
c_x &= 10
c_y &= 20
r_x &= 110
r_y &= 50
\varphi &= 35
\theta_1 &= 288
\theta_2 &= 20
With the equations above, we get these coordinates for the start and end positions (cf. the figure above):
.. math::
x_1 &= 65.1197
y_1 &= 0.5439
x_2 &= 84.8639
y_2 &= 93.2967
.. rubric:: Interpretation of StartAngle and EndAngle
These angles are not measured in the ellipse on which an :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc` is based, but in the unit circle:
???
The figure shows the end position w.r.t. the unit circle. Its angle measured from the horizonal semi-axis is :math:`\theta_2 = 20`. The ellipse could be constructed by stretching the unit circle by :math:`r_x` in direction of the horizontal semi-axis and by :math:`r_y` in direction of the vertical semi-axis. After this transformation, the end position w.r.t. the unit circle is at the actual end position.
To calculate an actual, ellipse-based angle from an angle w.r.t. the unit circle, use the formula
.. math::
\theta_{actual} = \textrm{atan2}( r_y \sin \theta, r_x \cos \theta ) \,\textrm{mod}\, 360 \quad.
The formulas apply to both the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc.StartAngle` :math:`\theta_1` and the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc.EndAngle` :math:`\theta_2`. Note that we give angles in degrees, i.e., the actual calculations in a program may require conversions to and from radians.
.. admonition:: example
In the example, we have
.. math::
\theta_{actual, 1} = \textrm{atan2}( 50 \cdotp \sin 288, 110 \cdotp \cos 288) \,\textrm{mod}\, 360 = 305.56
and
.. math::
\theta_{actual, 2} = \textrm{atan2}( 50 \cdotp \sin 20, 110 \cdotp \cos 20) \,\textrm{mod}\, 360 = 9.39 \quad .
The inverse formula is
.. math::
\theta = \textrm{atan2}( r_x \sin \theta_{actual}, r_y \cos \theta_{actual} ) \,\textrm{mod}\, 360 \quad .
.. admonition:: technical
The rationale for using angles w.r.t. the unit circle is that they are numerically more stable when an :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc` is scaled with small values (i.e., in a :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.ShapeUsage`) and that some calculations are simpler (cf. `SVG 2 Arc Implementation Notes <https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG2/implnote.html#ArcImplementationNotes>`__).
Mapping to SVG ==============
An :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc` is mapped to an `svg:path <https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG2/paths.html#PathElement>`__ with these attributes:
- :code:`d` is the `path data <https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG2/paths.html#PathData>`__ that describes the entire geometry of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc`. The value is the concatenation of the following strings, all of them separated by spaces:
- :code:`M`
- str(:math:`x_1`)
- str(:math:`y_1`)
- :code:`A`
- str(:math:`r_x`)
- str(:math:`r_y`)
- str(:math:`\varphi`)
- str(:math:`f_A`)
- :code:`1`
- str(:math:`x_2`)
- str(:math:`y_2`)
:math:`f_A` is calculated as follows (cf. the definition of the :ref:`modulo operator <modulo-operator>`):
.. math::
\Delta \theta &= (\theta_2 - \theta_1)\, \textrm{mod}\, 360 \quad ,
f_A &= 0 \quad \textrm{if} \, \Delta \theta < 180 \quad ,
f_A &= 1 \quad \textrm{if} \, \Delta \theta \geq 180 \quad .
The other variables have been defined above.
- :code:`stroke`, :code:`stroke-dasharray`, :code:`stroke-dashoffset` and :code:`stroke-width` are set according to the SVG mapping rules for the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc.Stroke` of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc` (see :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke`).
- :code:`stroke-linecap = "round"` and :code:`stroke-linejoin = "round"` reflect the :ref:`heuristic for line caps and line joins <line-caps-and-line-joins>`.
- :code:`vector-effect = "non-scaling-stroke"` reflects the :ref:`heuristic for scaled symbols <scaled-symbols>`.
- :code:`fill = "none"` is required to avoid that the `svg:path <https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG2/shapes.html#PolylineElement>`__ is filled.
.. admonition:: example
We assume that the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke` of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc` above is :code:`2mm #ff0000 solid`.
With :math:`\Delta \theta = (20 - 288)\, \textrm{{mod}}\,360 = (-268)\, \textrm{{mod}}\, 360 = 92 < 180` we get :math:`f_A = 0`.
.. code-block:: xml
{EllipseArcSolidSvgCode}
???
.. admonition:: example
We consider the same :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc` as in the previous example, except that the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke` is :code:`2mm #ff0000 Dash`.
.. code-block:: xml
{EllipseArcDashSvgCode}
.. image:: /images/img20.*

The X (horizontal) coordinate of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Point` in mm.
The Y (horizontal) coordinate of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Point` in mm.
A curve that consists of one or more chained straight sections.

Geometry ========
The first straight section of a :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.PolyLine` starts at its first :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Point`, i.e., :sp:element:`Points[0] <Core.Diagram.Polygon.Points>`, and ends at its second :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Point`. For each further :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Point`, another section is drawn that starts at the preceding :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Point`.
.. admonition:: example
We consider a :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.PolyLine` with 3 :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.PolyLine.Points`:
- :code:`(-30, 40)`,
- :code:`(50, 40)`, and
- :code:`(-10, -60)`.
The :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.PolyLine` will look like this:
.. image:: /images/img6.*
Mapping to SVG ==============
A :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.PolyLine` corresponds to an `svg:polyline <https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG2/shapes.html#PolylineElement>`__ with these attributes:
- :code:`points` contains the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.PolyLine.Points` of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.PolyLine`.
Each :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Point` :math:`i` with position :math:`x_i` and :math:`y_i` is converted to a string as str(:math:`x_i`) + :code:`,` + str(:math:`y_i`). Finally, the :code:`points` attribute is set to a single string that contains all positions, separated by spaces.
- :code:`stroke`, :code:`stroke-dasharray`, :code:`stroke-dashoffset` and :code:`stroke-width` are set according to the SVG mapping rules for the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.PolyLine.Stroke` of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.PolyLine` (see :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke`).
- :code:`stroke-linecap = "round"` and :code:`stroke-linejoin = "round"` reflect the :ref:`heuristic for line caps and line joins <line-caps-and-line-joins>`.
- :code:`vector-effect = "non-scaling-stroke"` reflects the :ref:`heuristic for scaled symbols <scaled-symbols>`.
- :code:`fill = "none"` is required to avoid that the `svg:polyline <https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG2/shapes.html#PolylineElement>`__ is filled.
.. admonition:: example
We assume that the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke` of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.PolyLine` above is :code:`2mm #007fff solid`.
.. code-block:: xml
{PolyLineSolidSvgCode}
.. image:: /images/img7.*
.. admonition:: example
We consider the same :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.PolyLine` as in the previous example, except that the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke` is :code:`2mm #007fff Dash`.
.. code-block:: xml
{PolyLineDashSvgCode}
.. image:: /images/img8.*
A figure that is delimited by a closed chain of three or more straight sections.

Geometry ========
The first straight section that delimits a :sp:element:`!~Core.Diagram.Polygon` starts at its first :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Point`, i.e., :sp:element:`Points[0] <Core.Diagram.Polygon.Points>`, and ends at its second :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Point`. For each further :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Point`, another section is added that starts at the preceding :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Point`. Finally, a section is added that starts at the last :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Point` and goes back to the first :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Point` such that the chain of sections is closed.
.. admonition:: example
We consider a :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Polygon` with 4 :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Polygon.Points`:
- :code:`(-30, 40)`,
- :code:`(50, 40)`,
- :code:`(-10, -60)`, and
- :code:`(-10, 0)`.
The :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Polygon` will look like this:
.. image:: /images/img9.*
.. rubric:: Interior of a Polygon
Depending on its :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Polygon.FillStyle`, the interior of a :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Polygon` may be filled. There are several possibilities to define when *"a point is inside a polygon"*. DEXPI applies a simple intuitive rule:
- Choose an arbitrary point outside the :ref:`geometric bounding box <geometric bounding box>` of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Polygon`.
- Each point that can be reached from there without crossing any segment is outside the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Polygon`.
- Each other point is inside the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Polygon`.
.. admonition:: example
The grey area in the figure visualizes the interior of the given :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Polygon`.
.. image:: /images/img10.*
.. admonition:: technical
In case of polygons, the DEXPI definition for interior points coincides with the *nonzero rule* in SVG. See `Section 13.4.2. of the SVG 2 Recommendation <https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG2/painting.html#WindingRule>`__ for a more precise definition of the *nonzero rule*.
The SVG 2 Recommendation also defines an alternative rule called *evenodd rule*. If we applied this rule, the pentagonal area in the center of this :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Polygon` would be considered outside:
.. image:: /images/img11.*
.. rubric:: Visual Center
Let :math:`n` be the number of :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Polygon.Points`, and let :math:`x_i` and :math:`y_i` be the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Point.X` and :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Point.Y` positions of :sp:element:`Point <Core.Diagram.Polygon.Points>` :math:`i` for :math:`0 \leq i < n`.
Then the horizontal position :math:`c_x` and the vertical position :math:`c_y` of the :ref:`visual center <visual-center>` of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Polygon` are
.. math::
c_x &= \frac 1 2 \Big[ \min_{i=0}^{n-1} x_i + \max_{i=0}^{n-1} x_i \Big] \quad ,
c_y &= \frac 1 2 \Big[ \min_{i=0}^{n-1} y_i + \max_{i=0}^{n-1} y_i \Big] \quad .
Intuitively, the :ref:`visual center <visual-center>` is the center of the minimum bounding box that contains all :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Polygon.Points`.
If the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Polygon` has the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Polygon.FillStyle` :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.FillStyle.Hatch`, then one of the hatch lines will cross through the visual center.
.. admonition:: example
For the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Polygon` above, we have
.. math::
c_x &= \frac 1 2 [ \min(-30, 50, -10, -10) + \max(-30, 50, -10, -10) ]
&= \frac 1 2 [-30 + 50]
&= 10
and
.. math::
c_y &= \frac 1 2 [ \min(40, 40, -60, 0) + \max(40, 40, -60, 0) ]
&= \frac 1 2 [-60 + 40]
&= -10 \quad .
Mapping to SVG ==============
A :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Polygon` corresponds to an `svg:polygon <https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG2/shapes.html#PolygonElement>`__ with these attributes:
- :code:`transform` contains a translation from the origin to the visual center. This is required due to the modified positions in :code:`points`.
:code:`transform = "translate(` + str(:math:`c_x`) + :code:`,` + str(:math:`c_y`) + :code:`)"`
- :code:`points` contains the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Polygon.Points` of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Polygon` *relative to the visual center*.
For each :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Point` :math:`i` with (absolute) position :math:`x_i` and :math:`y_i`, the position relative to the visual center is
.. math::
\tilde{x}_i &= x_i - c_x \quad ,
\tilde{y}_i &= y_i - c_y \quad .
Each of the relative positions is converted to a string as str(:math:`\tilde{x}_i`) + :code:`,` + str(:math:`\tilde{y}_i`). Finally, the :code:`points` attribute is set to a single string that contains all relative positions, separated by spaces.
- :code:`stroke`, :code:`stroke-dasharray`, :code:`stroke-dashoffset` and :code:`stroke-width` are set according to the SVG mapping rules for the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Polygon.Stroke` of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Polygon` (see :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke`).
- :code:`stroke-linecap = "round"` and :code:`stroke-linejoin = "round"` reflect the :ref:`heuristic for line caps and line joins <line-caps-and-line-joins>`.
- :code:`vector-effect = "non-scaling-stroke"` reflects the :ref:`heuristic for scaled symbols <scaled-symbols>`.
- :code:`fill` is set according to the SVG mapping rules for the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Polygon.FillStyle` of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Polygon` (see :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.FillStyle`).
.. admonition:: example
We assume that the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke` of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Polygon` above is :code:`2mm #ff00ff Solid` and that its :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Polygon.FillStyle` is :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.FillStyle.Transparent`.
.. code-block:: xml
{PolygonTransparentSvgCode}
.. image:: /images/img12.*
.. admonition:: example
We consider the same :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Polygon` as in the previous example, except that the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke` is :code:`2mm #ff00ff Dot`.
.. code-block:: xml
{PolygonDotSvgCode}
.. image:: /images/img13.*
.. admonition:: example
Finally, a variant with :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke` :code:`2mm #ff00ff Solid` and :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Polygon.FillStyle` :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.FillStyle.Hatch`.
.. code-block:: xml
{PolygonHatchSvgCode}
.. image:: /images/img14.*
A :sp:element:`!~Core.Diagram.RepresentationGroup` is a graphical representation of a :sp:element:`~Core.ConceptualObject`.

A registration number that identifies the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Shape`.
The following format is recommended:
:code:`[standard]:[version]-[id]-[transform]`
where
- :code:`standard` is the name of a drawing standard,
- :code:`version` is the version the drawing standard, e.g., a year,
- :code:`id` is the identifier used in the standard for the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Shape`,
- :code:`transform` gives the transformation of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Shape` w.r.t. its depiction in the standard.
:code:`transform` is one of the following values:
- :code:`A`: no transformation,
- :code:`B`: rotation by 90°,
- :code:`C`: rotation by 180°,
- :code:`D`: rotation by 270°,
- :code:`E`: mirrored,
- :code:`F`: mirrored, rotation by 90°,
- :code:`G`: mirrored, rotation by 180°,
- :code:`H`: mirrored, rotation by 270°.
The width of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke` in mm.
A stroke defines the visual appearance of a line.

Simplified Literals ===================
Within this specification, a simplified type of literal is used to refer to a :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke`. This literal is composed of
- a decimal representation of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke.Width`, followed by :code:`mm`,
- the simplified literal of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke.Color` of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke` (see :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Color`),
- the name of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke.DashStyle` of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke` (see :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.DashStyle`).
The three components are separated by spaces.
For example, a :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke` with
- :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke.Width` = :code:`2`,
- :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke.Color` = :code:`#00ff00`, and
- :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke.DashStyle` = :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.DashStyle.Dot`
is represented as :code:`2mm #00ff00 Dot`.
Mapping to SVG ==============
A :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke` is mapped to a set of XML attributes, which are added to the SVG element (e.g., a `svg:polygon <https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG2/shapes.html#PolygonElement>`__ or a `svg:polyline <https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG2/shapes.html#PolylineElement>`__ element) that is drawn with the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke`.
- The :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke.Color` of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke` is mapped to the :code:`stroke` attribute. For the attribute value, see the SVG mapping for :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Color`.
- The :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke.DashStyle` of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke` is mapped to the :code:`stroke-dasharray` and :code:`stroke-dashoffset` attributes as described in the SVG mapping for :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.DashStyle`. Note that these attribute values depend on the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke.Width` of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke` and on the :ref:`linecap` of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.GraphicalPrimitive` that uses the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke`.
- The :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke.Width` of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke` is mapped to the :code:`stroke-width` attribute. The attribute value is the concatenation of the string representation of the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke.Width` and the fixed string :code:`mm`. That is, in terms of :ref:`standard-css-values-4` we use an `absolute length <https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#absolute-lengths>`__ with the unit millimeters.
.. admonition:: example
For examples, see the SVG mapping sections of those subclasses of :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.GraphicalPrimitive` that have a :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Stroke` attribute:
- :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Ellipse` - :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.EllipseArc` - :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Polygon` - :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.PolyLine`
The template that describes how the text is built.

Two-dimensional engineering diagrams.
The :sp:element:`!~Core.Diagram` package provides concepts
1. for the graphical representation of a :sp:element:`~Core.ConceptualObject`,
2. for linking parts of this graphical representation to parts of the :sp:element:`~!Core.ConceptualObject`, and
3. for semantic annotations of the graphical representation.
.. admonition:: technical
This specification is not a drawing standard. It does not prescribe any drawing style or standard and it does not prescribe which information in a :sp:element:`~!Core.ConceptualObject` has to be represented in a :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Diagram`.
.. admonition:: technical
Until version 1.2, graphics has not been in the scope of the DEXPI P&ID Specification. Graphics was handled as prescribed by :ref:`standard-proteus`. Over the years, some best practices concerning graphics have evolved in the DEXPI community, and fragmentary annotations have been added to the DEXPI P&ID Specification.
In DEXPI P&ID Specification 1.3, an informative Graphics package was added to cover conceptual and graphics information in a single comprehensive model.
For the P&ID Specification 1.4, the Graphics package was further elaborated, and it is now a normative part of the specification. It serves to document the best practices that have emerged in the past, but no new features have been added.
The Graphics package is independent from Proteus Schema in the sense that it is a pure UML package. But, like for all other packages in this specification, mappings to Proteus Schema are defined that describe how instances of the package's types are serialized. In consequence, the features of the Graphics package are constrained to what is supported by Proteus Schema. Future versions of the DEXPI P&ID Specification will skip support for Proteus Schema, such that additional features can be added to the Graphics package depending on the DEXPI community's needs.
Since DEXPI 2.0, the Graphics package can be used for both P&IDs and process models.
Example -------
We consider a simple :sp:element:`~Core.ConceptualModel` :sp:name:`cm` that contains a single :sp:element:`~Plant.ProcessEquipment.CentrifugalPump` with two :sp:element:`ProcessNozzles <Plant.ProcessEquipment.ProcessNozzle>` and a :sp:element:`~Plant.ProcessEquipment.Chamber`; in total, there are five :sp:element:`ConceptualObjects <Core.ConceptualObject>`:
.. image:: /images/img0.*
A typical graphical representation of this model may look like this:
.. image:: /images/img1.*
Linking Graphics and Conceptual Objects ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
The graphics can be decomposed in parts each of which represents one of the :sp:element:`ConceptualObjects <Core.ConceptualObject>`. For each of these parts, we use a :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.RepresentationGroup`:
.. image:: /images/img2.*
- The :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Diagram` :sp:name:`d` represents the entire :sp:element:`~Core.ConceptualModel`. :sp:element:`!~Core.Diagram.Diagram` is a subclass of :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.RepresentationGroup` that is meant to be used for the entire graphics. In addition to a conventional :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.RepresentationGroup`, a :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Diagram` has a size (width and height) and a background color.
- :sp:name:`cp_grp` is the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.RepresentationGroup` for the :sp:element:`~Plant.ProcessEquipment.CentrifugalPump` :sp:name:`cp`.
- :sp:name:`pn1_grp` and :sp:name:`pn2_grp` represent the two :sp:element:`ProcessNozzles <Plant.ProcessEquipment.ProcessNozzle>` :sp:name:`pn1` and :sp:name:`pn2`.
Note that the composition hierarchy of the :sp:element:`!~Core.Diagram.Diagram` corresponds exactly to the composition hierarchy of the :sp:element:`~Core.ConceptualModel`. In the :sp:element:`~Core.ConceptualModel`, :sp:name:`pn1` is a component of :sp:name:`cp`, and in the :sp:element:`!~Core.Diagram.Diagram`, :sp:name:`pn1_grp` is a component of :sp:name:`cp_grp`.
However, if a :sp:element:`~Core.ConceptualObject` (including all its descendants) has no graphical representation at all, no :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.RepresentationGroup` is required: In the example above, there is no :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.RepresentationGroup` for the :sp:element:`~Plant.ProcessEquipment.Chamber` :sp:name:`ch`.
Adding Semantics ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
So far, we have decomposed the overall graphics in :sp:element:`RepresentationGroups <Core.Diagram.RepresentationGroup>` that correspond to certain :sp:element:`ConceptualObjects <Core.ConceptualObject>`. On a finer level of granularity, we can identify parts with different meanings. These meanings are covered by different subclasses of the abstract class :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.RepresentationTypeGroup`. In the example, two of these subclasses are used: :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Static` and :sp:element:`~Plant.Diagram.EquipmentTagNameLabel`.
.. image:: /images/img3.*
- Consider :sp:name:`cp_grp`, the :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.RepresentationGroup` of the :sp:element:`~Plant.ProcessEquipment.CentrifugalPump` :sp:name:`cp`. In addition to the two groups for the :sp:element:`ProcessNozzles <Plant.ProcessEquipment.ProcessNozzle>`, :sp:name:`cp_grp` now contains two :sp:element:`RepresentationTypeGroups <Core.Diagram.RepresentationTypeGroup>`.
- The :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Static` group contains the actual :sp:element:`~Plant.ProcessEquipment.CentrifugalPump` graphics without any annotations, labels, etc.
- The :sp:element:`~Plant.Diagram.EquipmentTagNameLabel` group displays the tag name of the :sp:element:`~Plant.ProcessEquipment.CentrifugalPump`.
- :sp:name:`pn1_grp` contains a :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Static` group for the basic symbol of the :sp:element:`~Plant.ProcessEquipment.ProcessNozzle`.
- :sp:name:`pn2_grp` contains another :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Static` group for the second :sp:element:`~Plant.ProcessEquipment.ProcessNozzle` symbol.
Whereas :sp:element:`RepresentationGroups <Core.Diagram.RepresentationGroup>` can be decomposed in further groups, :sp:element:`RepresentationTypeGroups <Core.Diagram.RepresentationTypeGroup>` cannot contain further groups.
Adding Graphical Elements ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
:sp:element:`RepresentationTypeGroups <Core.Diagram.RepresentationTypeGroup>` rather contain :sp:element:`GraphicalElements <Core.Diagram.GraphicalElement>` such as geometric primitives, texts, or :sp:element:`ShapeUsages <Core.Diagram.ShapeUsage>`.
.. image:: /images/img4.*
- The :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Static` group for the :sp:element:`~Plant.ProcessEquipment.CentrifugalPump` contains a :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.ShapeUsage`, i.e., a reference to a reusable :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Shape` with information about this specific usage (scaling, rotation, position).
- The :sp:element:`~Plant.Diagram.EquipmentTagNameLabel` for the :sp:element:`~Plant.ProcessEquipment.CentrifugalPump` contains a :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Text`.
- Both :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Static` groups for the two :sp:element:`ProcessNozzles <Plant.ProcessEquipment.ProcessNozzle>` contain a :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.ShapeUsage`.
Coordinate System -----------------
The coordinate system used is a 2D Cartesian system whose horizontal axis is oriented to the right and whose vertical axis is oriented to the bottom. In consequence, angles are measured clockwise.
Lengths are dimensionless. In the examples, we assume they are in millimeters.
.. admonition:: proteus
In Proteus Schema, the vertical axis to the top, and angles are measured anti-clockwise.
Mapping to SVG --------------
The purpose of these mappings is to define the visualization of instances of the types in this package, i.e., "how they look like".
In order to keep the mappings simple, the SVG mappings for all :sp:element:`GraphicalPrimitives <Core.Diagram.GraphicalPrimitive>` are defined such that they can be easily scaled when they appear in a :sp:element:`~Core.Diagram.Shape` (in particular, they use ``vector-effect = "non-scaling-stroke"``). In consequence, further scaling, e.g., in an application, will lead to unacceptable results.
.. admonition:: technical
The SVG mappings in this specification must not be misunderstood as a proposal for exchanging P&ID graphics via SVG.
.. _modulo-operator:
Modulo Operator ---------------
In some calculations for the SVG and Proteus mappings, the *modulo operator* (or *remainder of division*) is used. As the modulo operator can be defined in different ways, we give a definition of how the operator is used in this specification. We content ourselves with a definition for positive quotients.
Let :math:`q > 0, a \in \mathbb R`. Then
.. math::
a\,\textrm{mod}\,q = a - \left\lfloor \frac a q \right\rfloor \cdot q \quad .
:math:`\lfloor.\rfloor` is the *floor function* that for :math:`x \in \mathbb R` yields the largest integer :math:`n` such that :math:`n \leq x`.
For example,
.. math::
0\,\textrm{mod}\,360 &= 0 - \left\lfloor \frac {0} {360} \right\rfloor \cdot 360 = 0 - 0 \cdot 360 = 0 \quad, \\ 100\,\textrm{mod}\,360 &= 100 - \left\lfloor \frac {100} {360} \right\rfloor \cdot 360 = 100 - 0 \cdot 360 = 100 \quad, \\ 359\,\textrm{mod}\,360 &= 359 - \left\lfloor \frac {359} {360} \right\rfloor \cdot 360 = 359 - 0 \cdot 360 = 359 \quad, \\ 360\,\textrm{mod}\,360 &= 360 - \left\lfloor \frac {360} {360} \right\rfloor \cdot 360 = 360 - 1 \cdot 360 = 0 \quad, \\ (-100)\,\textrm{mod}\,360 &= -100 - \left\lfloor \frac {-100} {360} \right\rfloor \cdot 360 = -100 - (-1) \cdot 360 = 260 \quad. \\
.. admonition:: technical
The definition of the modulo operator differs between programming languages. For example, the modulo operator in Python, written :code:`%`, coincides with the definition above. The modulo operator in JavaScript (ECMAScript), also written :code:`%`, behaves differently for negative dividends: :code:`-100 % 360` is evaluated to :code:`-100`.
The date time at which the :sp:element:`~Core.EngineeringModel` was exported by the originating system (see :sp:element:`~Core.EngineeringModel.OriginatingSystemName`).
The name of the system from which the :sp:element:`~Core.EngineeringModel` originates, e.g., the name of a P&ID tool.
The name of the vendor of the system from which the :sp:element:`~Core.EngineeringModel` originates, e.g., the name of a software company.
The version of the the system from which the :sp:element:`~Core.EngineeringModel` originates, e.g., the version number of a tool.

An identifier for the :sp:element:`~Core.Note` in a local context.
A typical usage of the :sp:element:`!~Core.Note.LocalNoteIdentifier` is to visualize the relation between a :sp:element:`~Core.ConceptualObject` shown on a diagram and the actual :sp:element:`~Core.Note.NoteText` shown elsewhere on the diagram: The :sp:element:`!~Core.Note.LocalNoteIdentifier` would be drawn near the symbol of the :sp:element:`~Core.ConceptualObject`. A separate table would list the :sp:element:`!~Core.Note.LocalNoteIdentifier` and :sp:element:`~Core.Note.NoteText` attributes of all :sp:element:`Notes <Core.Note>` on the diagram.
A textual annotation about :sp:element:`ConceptualObjects <Core.ConceptualObject>`. See also :sp:element:`~Core.ConceptualObject.ReferencedNotes`.
The context of the :sp:element:`~Core.PersistentIdentifier` such as a database, a project number or name, etc.
The value of the :sp:element:`~Core.PersistentIdentifier`, i.e., the actual identifier string.
A persistent context-dependent identifier for a :sp:element:`~Core.ConceptualObject`.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *area* with dimension L\ :sup:`2`.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *density* with dimension L\ :sup:`-3`\ M.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *dynamic viscosity* with dimension L\ :sup:`-1`\ MT\ :sup:`-1`.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *electric current* with dimension I.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *electrical frequency* with dimension T\ :sup:`-1`.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *energy density* with dimension L\ :sup:`-1`\ MT\ :sup:`-2`.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *energy* with dimension L\ :sup:`2`\ MT\ :sup:`-2`.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *force* with dimension LMT\ :sup:`-2`.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *frequency* with dimension T\ :sup:`-1`. :sp:element:`!~Core.PhysicalQuantities.FrequencyUnit` has 3 subtypes for different application areas.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *heat capacity* with dimension L\ :sup:`2`\ MΘ\ :sup:`-1`\ T\ :sup:`-3`.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *heat transfer coefficient* with dimension MT\ :sup:`-3`\ Θ.
DEGREE FAHRENHEIT SQUARE FOOT HOUR PER BRITISH THERMAL UNIT
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *heat transfer resistance* with dimension M\ :sup:`-1`\ ΘT\ :sup:`3`.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *kinematic viscosity* with dimension L\ :sup:`2`\ T\ :sup:`-1`.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *length* with dimension L.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *magnetic field intensity* with dimension IL\ :sup:`-1`.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *magnetic flux density* with dimension MT\ :sup:`-2`\ I\ :sup:`-1`.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *mass concentration* with dimension L\ :sup:`-3`\ M.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *mass flow rate* with dimension MT\ :sup:`-1`.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *mass specific energy* with dimension L\ :sup:`2`\ T\ :sup:`-2`.
BRITISH THERMAL UNIT PER POUND MASS DEGREE FAHRENHEIT
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *mass specific heat capacity* with dimension L\ :sup:`2`\ Θ\ :sup:`-1`\ T\ :sup:`-2`.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *mass* with dimension M.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *mole concentration* with dimension NL\ :sup:`-3`.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *mole flow rate* with dimension NT\ :sup:`-1`.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *mole specific energy* with dimension N\ :sup:`-1`\ L\ :sup:`2`\ MT\ :sup:`-2`.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *moment of force* with dimension L\ :sup:`2`\ MT\ :sup:`-2`.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *number per time interval* with dimension T\ :sup:`-1`.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *particle size* with dimension L.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *percentage* with dimension 1.
A type parameter that gives the type of the :sp:element:`~Core.PhysicalQuantities.PhysicalQuantity.Unit`.
The unit of measurement of the :sp:element:`~Core.PhysicalQuantities.PhysicalQuantity`.

A quantification of a scalar physical property such as a length or a force. A :sp:element:`!~Core.PhysicalQuantities.PhysicalQuantity` comprises a numerical :sp:element:`~Core.PhysicalQuantities.PhysicalQuantity.Value` and a :sp:element:`~Core.PhysicalQuantities.PhysicalQuantity.Unit`.
A type parameter that gives the type of the :sp:element:`~Core.PhysicalQuantities.PhysicalQuantityVector.Unit`.
The unit of measurement of the :sp:element:`~Core.PhysicalQuantities.PhysicalQuantityVector`.

A quantification of a vector of physical properties such as length or force. A :sp:element:`!~Core.PhysicalQuantities.PhysicalQuantityVector` comprises an arbitrary number of :sp:element:`~Core.PhysicalQuantities.PhysicalQuantityVector.Values` and a :sp:element:`~Core.PhysicalQuantities.PhysicalQuantityVector.Unit`.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *power* with dimension L\ :sup:`2`\ MT\ :sup:`-3`.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *pressure absolute* with dimension L\ :sup:`-1`\ MT\ :sup:`-2`.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *pressure gauge* with dimension L\ :sup:`-1`\ MT\ :sup:`-2`.

A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *pressure* with dimension L\ :sup:`-1`\ MT\ :sup:`-2`. :sp:element:`!~Core.PhysicalQuantities.PressureUnit` has 2 subtypes for different application areas.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *rotational frequency* with dimension T\ :sup:`-1`.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *surface tension* with dimension MT\ :sup:`-2`.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *temperature* with dimension Θ.
BRITISH THERMAL UNIT PER HOUR FOOT DEGREE FAHRENHEIT
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *thermal conductivity* with dimension LMΘ\ :sup:`-1`\ T\ :sup:`-3`.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *time interval* with dimension T.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *velocity* with dimension LT\ :sup:`-1`.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *voltage* with dimension L\ :sup:`2`\ MT\ :sup:`-3`\ I\ :sup:`-1`.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *volume flow rate* with dimension L\ :sup:`3`\ T\ :sup:`-1`.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *volume* with dimension L\ :sup:`3`.
A unit of measurement for a physical quantity of type *pH* with dimension 1.
Data types for representing physical quantities such as the area of a surface and the frequency of a repeating event.
The identifier string for the case definition.
Globally unique identifier to the case referred to.
The display text of the :sp:element:`~Core.QualifiedValue`, typically shown in a diagram.
A reference to the definition of the :sp:element:`~Core.QualifiedValue`.
A reference to the source of the value.
General types for the representation of engineering information and associated graphical representations.
